title: What jobs or professions can be automated? - Quora

There is a report by McKinsey that helps us answer that question.[1] In other words, the report tries to assess which types of activities have the potential to be automated by adapting currently demonstrated technologies. Based on that those activities can be further discerned in seven categories as shown from the picture below coming from McKinsey Report:  Each of those categories indicates up to which extent (as percentage) can those activities be automated. As you can see each of those has a potential of automation: managing others can be automated up to 9%applying expertise can be automated up to 18%stakeholder interactions can be automated up to 20%unpredictable physical work can be automated up to 25%data collection can be automated up to 64%data processing can be automated up to 69%predictable physical work can be automated up to 78%Based on that the first people that will lose their jobs will be the workers on factories. Where their physical activities is repetitive and extremely predictable (where there are no sudden changes in the activity performed or the environment is predictable). According to the report welding and soldering on an assembly line can be almost entirely automated. Other jobs like construction and forestry (where the external environment is highly unpredictable) can only be automated by one fourth. Managing people instead seems to be the less prone to automation. In conclusion, to assess whether your job has already the potential to be automated you can look at the activity you perform on a daily basis. Asses for each of it in which category it falls into. Then assign how much of it you perform. That is how you’ll be able to assess if your job is about to be automated. For instance, if you work on an assembly line for 50% of your time. While the remaining half is spent managing other workers. Then, your job can be automated by 43.5% (9% * 50% + 78% * 50%). So you’re still safe! Of course this is a simplification. Yet those parameters are one of the most realistic ways to understand whether the job you perform can be automated. Footnotes[1] Where machines could replace humans--and where they can’t (yet)
